item.title: Practical quantum advantage in quantum simulation
item.author: Andrew J. Daley, Immanuel Bloch, Peter Zoller
item.content:encoded:
The current status and future perspectives for quantum simulation are overviewed, and the potential for practical quantum computational advantage is analysed by comparing classical numerical methods with analogue and digital quantum simulators.

Andrew J. Daley, Immanuel Bloch, Peter Zoller

item.title: Exponentially tighter bounds on limitations of quantum error mitigation
item.author: Yihui Quek, Daniel Stilck França, Jens Eisert
item.content:encoded:
Error mitigation has helped improve the performance of current quantum computing devices. Now, a mathematical analysis of the technique suggests its benefits may not extend to larger systems.

Yihui Quek, Daniel Stilck França, Jens Eisert

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: Deterministic multi-mode gates on a scalable photonic quantum computing platform
item.author: Mikkel V. Larsen, Xueshi Guo, Ulrik L. Andersen
item.content:encoded:
Measurement-based quantum computing performs quantum gates on entangled states without difficult multi-qubit coherent dynamics. A set of gates sufficient for universal quantum computing has now been implemented on a programmable optical platform.

Mikkel V. Larsen, Xueshi Guo, Ulrik L. Andersen

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: Quantum machine learning
item.author: Jacob Biamonte, Peter Wittek, Seth Lloyd
item.content:encoded:
Quantum machine learning software could enable quantum computers to learn complex patterns in data more efficiently than classical computers are able to.

Jacob Biamonte, Peter Wittek, Seth Lloyd

Nature - Reviews

item.title: Integrated photonic quantum technologies
item.author: Jianwei Wang, Fabio Sciarrino, Mark G. Thompson
item.content:encoded:
This Review covers recent progress in integrated quantum photonics (IQP) technologies and their applications. The challenges and opportunities of realizing large-scale, monolithic IQP circuits for future quantum applications are discussed.

Jianwei Wang, Fabio Sciarrino, Mark G. Thompson

Nature Photonics - Reviews

item.title: Towards a global quantum network
item.author: Christoph Simon
item.content:encoded:
The creation of a global quantum network is now a realistic proposition thanks to developments in satellite and fibre links and quantum memory. Applications will range from secure communication and fundamental physics experiments to a future quantum internet.

Christoph Simon

Nature Photonics - Comments & Opinion

item.title: Advances in quantum teleportation
item.author: S. Pirandola, J. Eisert, S. L. Braunstein
item.content:encoded:
This review covers state-of-the-art quantum teleportation technologies, from photonic qubits and optical modes to atomic ensembles, trapped atoms and solid-state systems. Open issues and potential future implementations are also discussed.

S. Pirandola, J. Eisert, S. L. Braunstein

Nature Photonics - Reviews

item.title: Photonic quantum simulators
item.author: Alán Aspuru-Guzik, Philip Walther
item.content:encoded:
Quantum optics has played an important role in the exploration of foundational issues in quantum mechanics, and in using quantum effects for information processing and communications purposes. Photonic quantum systems now also provide a valuable test bed for quantum simulations. This article surveys the first generation of such experiments, and discusses the prospects for tackling outstanding problems in physics, chemistry and biology.

Alán Aspuru-Guzik, Philip Walther

item.title: Photonic quantum technologies
item.author: Jeremy L. O'Brien, Akira Furusawa, Jelena Vučković
item.content:encoded:
We have just witnessed the birth of the first quantum technology based on encoding information in light for quantum key distribution. The quantum nature of light seems destined to continue to have a central role in future technologies. Here we provide a broad review of photonics for quantum technologies touching on topics including secure communication with photons, quantum information processing, quantum lithography and integrated quantum photonics.

Jeremy L. O'Brien, Akira Furusawa, Jelena Vučković

Nature Photonics - Reviews

item.title: Protecting entanglement between logical qubits via quantum error correction
item.author: Weizhou Cai, Xianghao Mu, Luyan Sun
item.content:encoded:
Despite being essential to many applications in quantum science, entanglement can be easily disrupted by decoherence. A protocol based on repetitive quantum error correction now demonstrates enhanced coherence times of entangled logical qubits.

Weizhou Cai, Xianghao Mu, Luyan Sun

item.title: Quantum leaps in small steps
item.author: Tommaso Calarco, Philippe Grangier, Peter Zoller
item.content:encoded:
Only long-term commitment can ensure that quantum information science eventually fulfils its promise of revolutionizing information-based societies.

Tommaso Calarco, Philippe Grangier, Peter Zoller

Nature Physics - Comments & Opinion

item.title: Optical quantum memory
item.author: Alexander I. Lvovsky, Barry C. Sanders, Wolfgang Tittel
item.content:encoded:
Quantum memory is important for a range of application including quantum information processing, matching various processes within a quantum devices, as a tool to convert photons to photons-on-demand and for implementation of long-distance quantum communication using quantum repeaters. Here, state-of-the-art optical quantum memory is reviewed.

Alexander I. Lvovsky, Barry C. Sanders, Wolfgang Tittel

item.title: Self-verifying variational quantum simulation of lattice models
item.author: C. Kokail, C. Maier, P. Zoller
item.content:encoded:
Quantum-classical variational techniques are combined with a programmable analogue quantum simulator based on a one-dimensional array of up to 20 trapped calcium ions to simulate the ground state of the lattice Schwinger model.

C. Kokail, C. Maier, P. Zoller

Nature - Research

item.title: Quantum computational supremacy
item.author: Aram W. Harrow, Ashley Montanaro
item.content:encoded:
Proposals for demonstrating quantum supremacy, when a quantum computer supersedes any possible classical computer at a specific task, are reviewed.

Aram W. Harrow, Ashley Montanaro

Nature - Reviews

item.title: Quantum simulation of the wavefunction to probe frustrated Heisenberg spin systems
item.author: Xiao-song Ma, Borivoje Dakic, Philip Walther
item.content:encoded:
Quantum simulations, where one quantum system is used to emulate another, are starting to become experimentally feasible. Here, four-photon states are used to simulate spin tetramers, which are important in the description of certain solid-state systems. Emerging frustration within the tetramer is observed, as well as evolution of the ground state from a localized to a resonating-valence-bond state.

Xiao-song Ma, Borivoje Dakic, Philip Walther

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: A versatile single-photon-based quantum computing platform
item.author: Nicolas Maring, Andreas Fyrillas, Niccolo Somaschi
item.content:encoded:
A versatile cloud-accessible single-photon-based quantum computing machine is developed, which shows a six-photon sampling rate of 4 Hz over weeks. Heralded generation of a three-photon Greenberger–Horne–Zeilinger state—a key milestone toward measurement-based quantum computing—is implemented.

Nicolas Maring, Andreas Fyrillas, Niccolo Somaschi

Nature Photonics - Research

item.title: The AI–quantum computing mash-up: will it revolutionize science?
item.author: Davide Castelvecchi
item.content:encoded:
Scientists are exploring the potential of quantum machine learning. But whether there are useful applications for the fusion of artificial intelligence and quantum computing is unclear.

Davide Castelvecchi

Nature - News

item.title: Beyond quantum supremacy: the hunt for useful quantum computers
item.author: Michael Brooks
item.content:encoded:
Researchers search for ways to put today’s small noisy quantum systems to work.

Michael Brooks

Nature - News

item.title: Distributed quantum computing across an optical network link
item.author: D. Main, P. Drmota, D. M. Lucas
item.content:encoded:
The distribution of quantum computations is demonstrated between two photonically interconnected trapped-ion modules, using repeatable, deterministic teleported controlled-Z gates to perform Grover’s search algorithm.

D. Main, P. Drmota, D. M. Lucas

Nature - Research

item.title: Satellite-to-ground quantum key distribution
item.author: Sheng-Kai Liao, Wen-Qi Cai, Jian-Wei Pan
item.content:encoded:
Decoy-state quantum key distribution from a satellite to a ground station is achieved with much greater efficiency than is possible over the same distance using optical fibres.

Sheng-Kai Liao, Wen-Qi Cai, Jian-Wei Pan

Nature - Research

item.title: Quantum advantage with noisy shallow circuits
item.author: Sergey Bravyi, David Gosset, Marco Tomamichel
item.content:encoded:
Uncorrected noise prevents quantum computers from running deep algorithms and outperforming classical machines. A method is now reported that allows noisy shallow quantum algorithms to be used to solve classically hard problems.

Sergey Bravyi, David Gosset, Marco Tomamichel

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: Measurement-induced quantum phases realized in a trapped-ion quantum computer
item.author: Crystal Noel, Pradeep Niroula, Christopher Monroe
item.content:encoded:
Many-body open quantum systems are predicted to undergo a phase transition towards a pure state through frequent projective measurements. The phases separated by this transition have now been observed with random circuits on a trapped-ion computer.

Crystal Noel, Pradeep Niroula, Christopher Monroe

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: Drug design on quantum computers
item.author: Raffaele Santagati, Alan Aspuru-Guzik, Clemens Utschig-Utschig
item.content:encoded:
Quantum computers promise to efficiently predict the structure and behaviour of molecules. This Perspective explores how this could overcome existing challenges in computational drug discovery.

Raffaele Santagati, Alan Aspuru-Guzik, Clemens Utschig-Utschig

Nature Physics - Reviews

item.title: A manufacturable platform for photonic quantum computing
item.author: Koen Alexander, Avishai Benyamini, Xinran Zhou
item.content:encoded:
A manufacturable platform for quantum computing with photons is introduced and a set of monolithically integrated silicon-photonics-based modules is benchmarked, demonstrating dual-rail photonic qubits with performance close to thresholds required for operation.

Koen Alexander, Avishai Benyamini, Xinran Zhou

Nature - Research

item.title: Simulating two-dimensional lattice gauge theories on a qudit quantum computer
item.author: Michael Meth, Jinglei Zhang, Martin Ringbauer
item.content:encoded:
Qubit-based simulations of gauge theories are challenging as gauge fields require high-dimensional encoding. Now a quantum electrodynamics model has been demonstrated using trapped-ion qudits, which encode information in multiple states of ions.

Michael Meth, Jinglei Zhang, Martin Ringbauer

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: Happy centenary, photon
item.author: Anton Zeilinger, Gregor Weihs, Markus Aspelmeyer
item.content:encoded:
No Description

Anton Zeilinger, Gregor Weihs, Markus Aspelmeyer

Nature - Reviews

item.title: Contextuality supplies the ‘magic’ for quantum computation
item.author: Mark Howard, Joel Wallman, Joseph Emerson
item.content:encoded:
Quantum computing promises advantages over classical computing for certain problems; now ‘quantum contextuality’ — a generalization of the concept of quantum non-locality — is shown to be a critical resource that gives the most promising class of quantum computers their power.

Mark Howard, Joel Wallman, Joseph Emerson

Nature - Research

item.title: High-efficiency single-photon source above the loss-tolerant threshold for efficient linear optical quantum computing
item.author: Xing Ding, Yong-Peng Guo, Jian-Wei Pan
item.content:encoded:
By resonant excitation of an InAs quantum dot embedded in a microcavity, a deterministic single-photon source is demonstrated. Single-photon purity of 0.9795(6), photon indistinguishability of 0.9856(13), and an overall end-to-end efficiency of 0.712(18) are simultaneously obtained.

Xing Ding, Yong-Peng Guo, Jian-Wei Pan

Nature Photonics - Research

item.title: Experimental quantum key distribution certified by Bell's theorem
item.author: D. P. Nadlinger, P. Drmota, J.-D. Bancal
item.content:encoded:
This study demonstrates the experimental realization of a complete protocol for quantum key distribution using entangled trapped strontium ions with device-independent quantum security guarantees.

D. P. Nadlinger, P. Drmota, J.-D. Bancal

Nature - Research

item.title: Advances in photonic quantum sensing
item.author: S. Pirandola, B. R. Bardhan, S. Lloyd
item.content:encoded:
This Review discusses emerging applications of photonic quantum sensing. The theoretical and experimental developments of quantum reading of classical data, quantum illumination of targets, and optical resolution beyond the Rayleigh limit are described.

S. Pirandola, B. R. Bardhan, S. Lloyd

Nature Photonics - Reviews

item.title: Long-distance free-space quantum key distribution in daylight towards inter-satellite communication
item.author: Sheng-Kai Liao, Hai-Lin Yong, Jian-Wei Pan
item.content:encoded:
The feasibility of satellite-assisted quantum communication is demonstrated by a field test on the ground. To supress noise due to sunlight the wavelength of 1,550 nm is chosen, and spectrum and spatial filtering technology developed.

Sheng-Kai Liao, Hai-Lin Yong, Jian-Wei Pan

Nature Photonics - Research

item.title: Demonstration of fault-tolerant universal quantum gate operations
item.author: Lukas Postler, Sascha Heuβen, Thomas Monz
item.content:encoded:
A fault-tolerant, universal set of single- and two-qubit quantum gates is demonstrated between two instances of the seven-qubit colour code in a trapped-ion quantum computer.

Lukas Postler, Sascha Heuβen, Thomas Monz

Nature - Research

item.title: Hybrid entanglement and bit-flip error correction in a scalable quantum network node
item.author: Xiu-Ying Chang, Pan-Yu Hou, Lu-Ming Duan
item.content:encoded:
Nodes in a quantum network must be able to interface with photonic qubits as well as perform local quantum computations. The quantum node device presented here is capable of storing quantum information and correcting bit-flip errors.

Xiu-Ying Chang, Pan-Yu Hou, Lu-Ming Duan

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: Interactive cryptographic proofs of quantumness using mid-circuit measurements
item.author: Daiwei Zhu, Gregory D. Kahanamoku-Meyer, Christopher Monroe
item.content:encoded:
Being able to perform qubit measurements within a quantum circuit and adapt to their outcome broadens the power of quantum computers. These mid-circuit measurements have now been used to implement a cryptographic proof of non-classical behaviour.

Daiwei Zhu, Gregory D. Kahanamoku-Meyer, Christopher Monroe

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: Quantum information transfer using photons
item.author: T. E. Northup, R. Blatt
item.content:encoded:
Recent advances in quantum information transfer by photons are reviewed. The theoretical framework for information transfer between nodes of a quantum network is described, and several key experiments for remote atom–atom entanglement mediated by light are illustrated. The prospects for hybrid systems currently in development are also discussed.

T. E. Northup, R. Blatt

Nature Photonics - Reviews

item.title: Quantum computing
item.author: Emanuel Knill
item.content:encoded:
The race is on to build a computer that exploits quantum mechanics. Such a machine could solve problems in physics, mathematics and cryptography that were once thought intractable, revolutionizing information technology and illuminating the foundations of physics. But when?

Emanuel Knill

Nature - Comments & Opinion

item.title: Experimental quantum repeater without quantum memory
item.author: Zheng-Da Li, Rui Zhang, Jian-Wei Pan
item.content:encoded:
An all-photonic quantum repeater is demonstrated by manipulating state-of-the-art 12-photon interferometry. The enhancement of entanglement-generation rate compared with parallel entanglement swapping proves the feasibility of the concept.

Zheng-Da Li, Rui Zhang, Jian-Wei Pan

Nature Photonics - Research

item.title: Quantum information processing and quantum optics with circuit quantum electrodynamics
item.author: Alexandre Blais, Steven M. Girvin, William D. Oliver
item.content:encoded:
The introduction of concepts from cavity quantum electrodynamics to superconducting circuits yielded circuit quantum electrodynamics, a platform eminently suitable to quantum information processing and for the exploration of novel regimes in quantum optics.

Alexandre Blais, Steven M. Girvin, William D. Oliver

Nature Physics - Reviews

item.title: Holographic dynamics simulations with a trapped-ion quantum computer
item.author: Eli Chertkov, Justin Bohnet, Michael Foss-Feig
item.content:encoded:
The simulation of quantum dynamics is a challenging task to solve with classical resources. An experiment with a trapped-ion quantum processor now shows the efficient simulation of the evolution of large-scale many-body quantum systems.

Eli Chertkov, Justin Bohnet, Michael Foss-Feig

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: Experimental one-way quantum computing
item.author: P. Walther, K. J. Resch, A. Zeilinger
item.content:encoded:
No Description

P. Walther, K. J. Resch, A. Zeilinger

Nature - Research

item.title: An operating system for executing applications on quantum network nodes
item.author: C. Delle Donne, M. Iuliano, S. Wehner
item.content:encoded:
A new quantum operating system architecture is described that is capable of executing applications on quantum networks in high-level software, which is a step towards bringing quantum network technology to society.

C. Delle Donne, M. Iuliano, S. Wehner

Nature - Research

item.title: High-threshold and low-overhead fault-tolerant quantum memory
item.author: Sergey Bravyi, Andrew W. Cross, Theodore J. Yoder
item.content:encoded:
An end-to-end quantum error correction protocol that implements fault-tolerant memory on the basis of a family of low-density parity-check codes shows the possibility of low-overhead fault-tolerant quantum memory within the reach of near-term quantum processors.

Sergey Bravyi, Andrew W. Cross, Theodore J. Yoder

Nature - Research

item.title: Quantum simulations with trapped ions
item.author: R. Blatt, C. F. Roos
item.content:encoded:
Experimental progress in controlling and manipulating trapped atomic ions has opened the door for a series of proof-of-principle quantum simulations. This article reviews these experiments, together with the methods and tools that have enabled them, and provides an outlook on future directions in the field.

R. Blatt, C. F. Roos

Nature Physics - Reviews

item.title: Quantum supremacy using a programmable superconducting processor
item.author: Frank Arute, Kunal Arya, John M. Martinis
item.content:encoded:
Quantum supremacy is demonstrated using a programmable superconducting processor known as Sycamore, taking approximately 200 seconds to sample one instance of a quantum circuit a million times, which would take a state-of-the-art supercomputer around ten thousand years to compute.

Frank Arute, Kunal Arya, John M. Martinis

Nature - Research

item.title: Quantum error correction and universal gate set operation on a binomial bosonic logical qubit
item.author: L. Hu, Y. Ma, L. Sun
item.content:encoded:
Repeated error correction creates a logical qubit encoded in the hybrid state of a superconducting circuit and a bosonic cavity, which is shown to be fully controllable under a universal single-qubit gate set.

L. Hu, Y. Ma, L. Sun

Nature Physics - Research

item.title: Demonstration of the trapped-ion quantum CCD computer architecture
item.author: J. M. Pino, J. M. Dreiling, B. Neyenhuis
item.content:encoded:
The quantum charge-coupled device architecture is demonstrated, with its various elements integrated into a programmable trapped-ion quantum computer and performing simple quantum operations with state-of-the-art levels of error.

J. M. Pino, J. M. Dreiling, B. Neyenhuis

Nature - Research
